description.text:
This is a camera rig for use with Autodesk's 123D Catch software and service. 123D Catch lets you generate a detailed 3D model of an object from a collection of photographs.
The rig described here helps you structure the photos for best results. It lets you spin the camera around the object at a constant height and distance, while the object stays still. You can easily move the camera up and down to get top and bottom angles.

The rig requires wooden dowels and some hardware to assemble, but takes about 20 minutes to put together. It breaks down for transport in less than a minute. You will need: Wood materials 3x 36" long 1" dia dowel
1x 12" long x 3/4" thick x 2" wide plank
1x 8" x 8" x 3/4" board
1x 6" x 6" x 3/4" board Printed parts 1x l-brace
1x 3-brace
2x 2-brace
2x 1-brace
1x collar
2x flange
3x shaft collar
1x camera ring
1x camera platform
1x extension arm (optional) Hardware 38x #8 3/4" construction screws
4x #8 3/4" hex bolt
1x #8 1" hex bolt
5x #8 wing nuts (6x optional)
2x #8 lock washers (3x optional)
1x 1/4" x 3/4" thumbscrew
1x 1/4 washer
2x casters Assembly steps
  • Print the plastic parts! The L-brace and the collar piece will benefit from printing with support material enabled. The other pieces print fine without support.
  • Take one piece of dowel, and cut it into 2x 4" pieces, and 2x 8" pieces
  • Mark center of 12" plank
  • Attach l-brace to plank with 4x #8 screws
  • Place a 4" dowel in each side of the 3-brace
  • Place an 8" dowel in the middle of the 3-brace
  • Insert the 8" dowel into the top of the l-brace
  • Fit a 1-brace onto the free end of the 4" dowels
  • Bring the one braces down to the plank. Make sure the 4" dowels are tightly seated, into the 3-brace on one end, and a 1-brace on the other end
  • Attach the 1-braces to the plank using 8x #8 screws
  • Secure the 4" dowels to the 1-brace and 3-brace by using 4x #8 screws (2 on each side)
  • Do NOT secure the 8" dowel
  • Attach the casters to the bottom of the plank using 8X #8 screws
  • Put a 2-brace on each end of one piece of 8" dowel (do not secure using a screw yet)
  • Attach the collar to the end of one 36" dowel
  • Attach the flange to the 8" x 8" board using 4x #8 screws
  • Attach the other flange to the 6" x 6" board using 4x #8 screws
  • Assemble the shaft collars by putting a #8 hex bolt through one side, and secure it with a #8 wing nut (do not tighten)
  • Slide one end of the 8" dowel with the 2-braces over the other 8" dowel (in the 3-brace)
  • Put a shaft collar on the dowel with the collar, and slide it down towards the center
  • Fit the long dowel with the collar through the other 2-brace and then through the bottom of the l-brace
  • Ensure the 2-braces are lined up and secure them with 2x #8 screw
  • Remove the 8" dowel and place it in the flange, secure it with 1x #8 screw
  • Put a shaft collar over the 8" dowel in the flange
  • Put the collar on the end of the long dowel over the short dowel in the flange
  • Adjust the height of the shaft collar so that the long dowel is level
  • Place the other long dowel in the top of the 3-brace, threading it through the loose 2-brace
  • Place the small platform (with flange) over the short dowel that is attached to the bottom plate
  • Place a shaft collar on the outside of the long horizontal dowel
  • Assemble the camera adapter by putting a #8 hex bolt through the two tabs, and secure it with a wing nut
  • Attach the camera platform to the camera adapter with a "1 #8 hex bolt, and placing a lock washer between the adapter ring and the platform. Secure with a wing nut.
  • Attach the camera mount assembly to the vertical pole by slipping it over and then tightening the wing nut
  • If you need to get the camera below the level of the target object, use the extension arm between the adapter ring and the camera platform.

comments.text: Wow, how's this working for you?  I'm working on a 123D Catch (god, I hate that name) rig, but ended up deciding to turn-table the object with LED lights.  It works, but has to be used in a dark room or environmental lights mess up the scan.
comments.author: BenitoSanduchi

comments.text: It works really well. We tried the turntable approach, but the inconsistent lighting caused problems with the software. It is important that the shadows stay in the same place!
comments.author: BenitoSanduchi

comments.text: I'm using a stationary overhead light, centered with a plum line and then two small fill lights (which may change to four) that spin with the platform.  So my lights don't move in relation to the object.  Got a really good scan with it last night that printed great.
comments.author: gpvillamil

description.text:
This is a base that can be used to support larger flower pots. In my case, I use three of these for every pot that I want supported. Background: Several years ago, my wife purchased some cement rabbit-shaped figures to support potted plants on our patio. Recently, one of these cracked and needed to be repaired. We were unable to find a replacement, so I turned to the Digitizer to try and scan and print a replacement. This object is the results of that effort. I originally scanned the object in early October when I first got my
Makerbot Digitizer. The original scanned object was ok, but the platform in the back of the model was uneven. In late November, Makerbot released version 2.40 of the software which combines multiple scans of the same object. (MultiScan). Using this version, I was able to rescan the original object and obtain a much cleaner model. This object was scanned twice. Once in the normal position, and once on its side with the back platform directly facing the front of the Digitizer.

description.text:
This is an organic vase with planet-like spheres spiraling upward to create a unique artistic vase. Version 8 adds cross branches for stability.

Important Note:: I have done some tests and I don't think version 1 is printable on a normal deposition (FFF) type of printers. The undulating branches have too much give. I have even tried it on a larger printer (Ultimaker Extended). It will probably work on an SLA type printers. I don't have access to an SLA printer so please report any success printing this model.

Update: I have created version 8 which adds branches going the opposite direction to add stability. This version is at a lower resolution because of file size restrictions on Thingiverse. This version should be printable but the problem is one set of the branches might need supports - may have gotten those too horizontal.

description.text:
This is an assassin's creed belt buckle that you can wear.
LINKS:

The MatterHackers Controller:
http://www.mattercontrol.com/

Go check out my new website: http://www.galacticgentleman.com/home/

If you liked this you might also like my other projects on my page.
http://www.thingiverse.com/Outlandish_Gamer/about

Did you like this design? If so make it your own! I have a blank belt buckle you can customize here --> http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1943204

Would you like to be up to date on my new designs? Link to my Twitter
https://twitter.com/?lang=en

Have Fun and Print On!

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Any

Infill:

10-30%

Notes:

I highly recommend using Matterhackers mattercontrol 1.6 if you are controlling your 3D printer from your computer via USB connection. This program is free and easy to use and produces very high quality prints. I switched from Cura because I was having issues with the prints, However with this program I have had no problems what-so-ever even on longer prints. I also suggest using Elmer's glue stick or other glue sticks on top of tape on your printing bed; This helps a lot with bed adhesion.

Disclaimer:
I am not in any way affiliated with MatterHackers. They have a great software that I use on a daily basis. Link in the summery.
This is how mine turned out with normal settings, However my print bed was not leveled prior to printing, that is why the face looks like it does.

I designed the buckle first (I have a blank one you can customize here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1943204 ) using fusion 360 then I joined it with the logo I modeled off a canvas.
Picture used for the canvas: http://www.crochetville.com/community/topic/149129-assassins-creed-pattern-for-logo/

description.text:
This is my own design. It is designed for an S&W M&P 40. I know it will fit the 9mm version of the S&W and will likely work with other double stack mags.

There are two parts and are designed based on printing with ABS and then fusing them together at the angle you prefer. I have not tried to print with any other material but could potentially use anything else and then glue the two section together.

The screw is an m3 and there is a slot to drop the m3 nut in.

Also I have attached two version of the files one includes a base heat shield. This helps with my open printer to print without warping.

author: FallenXBlade

title: Dogbert's Stepper Extruder Cooler Plus Filament Tube Cooler

description.text: I've been struggling with PLA and have three or four almost full rolls that won't extrude. Before completing Dogbert's stepper cooler mod on my one Up and two Afinia printers I added a feature to the stepper cap. I made an air channel that can be opened or closed that blows on the metal filament tube above the heater block. If it doesn't make a difference for cooling or causes other issues by blowing hot air around the nozzle it's easy to turn off. I also cored out some features to minimize needed support (with support angle <30 degrees). Prints great in ABS at 0.25mm, fan side down.

description.text:
Just a simple holder that clips or bolts to one of the tripod legs on a Skywatcher eq3-2 tripod that holds the manual motor controller box. Designed in Tinkercad and then tweaked and twisted in 123D.

1 version is without the screw mounting hole and the other version is with the screw mounting hole.

No

Doesn't Matter

0.25

25%

Notes:

For speed and quick printing I use 0.50 nozel @ 0.25 then once final design I change down to 0.40 @ 0.20. This should work fine in either abs, pla hips etc.

I modeled the fin for the bottom part of the handle. Otherwise, everything else is borrowed from the original gun. Recommended print at 200 microns and use about 10-15% infill for all large parts and use 100% infill for small or tiny parts. I used hobby enamel paint for the stripes on the top as well as a few other decals on the gun.

description.text:
This is a visio stencil for OpenLOCK systems. The easier to plan your dungeon out!

(You don't need the dxf file... thats there to make thingiverse happy.)

NOTE: These files have been updated to the latest OpenLOCK 5 standard: http://www.printablescenery.com/knowledgebase/openlock-developer-information/.

Note: For those (without Visio) who are looking to print this for paper dungeon planning, please see my corresponding project: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2512283.

Or: For those with image editing skills, download the 'OpenLOCK 5 reference.zip', which has a 200dpi png w/ transperency export of all the shapes. Shapes are all on .25" grid boundaries.
Don't try to laser cut the .dxf files. The snap pattern is not the true OpenLOCK connector. This is for planning only, not fabrication.

description.text:
This knot was created in Moment of Inspiration (MoI) from a script written by user bemfarmer based on work by Aaron Trautwein.
IT HAS NO USEFUL PURPOSE - but it looks nice, and the shape would be a serious challenge for subtractive manufacturing.
Note that this does require support and, I think, a raft.
I found it pretty easy to print in PETG on a Prusa Original i3 Mk2 using Simplify 3D as the slicer.
PETG is currently my favourite material. Looks good, stick well to the build plate and supports come away fairly easily.
I printed the knot 'sitting down' and 'standing up'. Both shown in the photos. The 'standing up' variant took significantly less time and material.

Printer:

Prusa Original i3 Mk2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10%

Notes:

For Simplify 3D users - I disabled 'Raft base layers'
After removing the raft and support material I did a little light filing.

This knot was created in Moment of Inspiration (MoI) from a script written by user bemfarmer based on work by Aaron Trautwein.
I did little more than experiment with the options and then swept a circle over the curve provided by Brian's script.

After breaking the Dec RJ11/RJ12 connector and designing a cover to keep it a bit safer (dec motor cover http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1955890) I had to blast on and do the R.A motor as well, Just to sort of keep them matching. This one requires an 8mm M3 nut and bolt jast as the Dec motor but I also decided to move the RJ11/RJ12 connector from the metal support bracket and include it in the cover ( simmilar to the Dec motor) I used hot melt gule to secure the grey connector but I am sure 2 pack glue etc will work just as good.

Printer:

ctc rep dual sailfished

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

0.25

Deconstructions
  1. Remove the motor unit from the tripod.
  2. Remove the 2 small screws that hold the RJ11/RJ12 connector board from the metal bracket.
  3. Slide the RJ11/RJ12 connector board into the printed part from behind and fire up the glue gun / mix and run a bead of glue round the outside edge of the RJ11/RJ12 connector and the printed part.
  4. Once the glue has dried / cooled and set remove the upper motor mount screw and line the printed part up to the screw hold and insert the new screw and tighten up.

Design work

I start everything in Tinkercad to get a rough part prototyped. Once I get something that looks and fits I then change over to 123D to tweak and finalise the design.

description.text:
!!!!!!!!In Cura Print with at least 7 percent support touching build plate using triangles. Or more of what ever other style you want
0.3mm layer or smaller 20 percent infill or more

fits on my i3 179mm by 180mm
Sorry to the first 2 downloaders I hald the centers in the wrong directions. It is now fixed.

The whole reason for this is I bought a wood prusa i3 pro b style from ebay. It has terrible flex in the center as well as the front and rear. Im trying to make my printer bullet proof.

The y axis would shift back and fourth the center brace stopped that. The original motor mounts were weak. Pep cowboy added some the were a bit short and i found if you tip the printer on its side to get a wire or something the mount would snap. So a made them taller added a support between the sides.

I had these crappy clamps that stripped out for holding the smooth rod from moving. So i added clamps to the smooth rods to eliminate these.

This is a mashup of 2 designs

Out on many places like eBay, you can purchase a very cheap replacement controller for your NES which is shaped like the 2nd generation "dogbone" controller for the NES. Unlike the official NES dogbone controller, the third party ones (such as the Tomee controller I have here) do not have a pivot for the D-Pad to rock on physically preventing opposite directions from being pressed at the same time. As a consequence, this Tomee controller gives a strange behavior of being able to push all 4 directions at the same time which causes really weird behavior in NES games. Another odd thing about these third party controllers is that they actually do have a pivot inside the D-Pad, it is just not usable since nothing actually touches it. This is what this "thing" is designed to fix.

How to do this:
1) Remove all 5 screws on the back of the controller. You will have to break the QC Quality (lol) Check sticker.
2) Remove the wire wrapped around the stand-offs and then carefully remove the board out of the controller.
3) Insert the pivot into the D-Pad. It should not rotate, but even if it does, it shouldn't be much of a problem.

Optional: You may want to glue the pivot to the silicone pad so it doesn't rock around or move out of place.

Optional 2: You may want to place a piece of smooth tape on the top of the pivot so the roughness of the 3D print doesn't sand down the pivot on the D-Pad.

author: nostocales

title: STEP Calibration Piece (X, Y and Z axis)

description.text:
To get dimensionally accurate printouts the printer has to be calibrated appropriately. I found that my Ultimaker had some issues reproducing technical models accurately leading to issues with fit of screw holes, etc. This calibration piece allows to adjust the X,Y and Z-STEPS appropriately. Just print this piece and then carefully measure the 3 sides with a Caliper. Make sure you don't include the first layers as they usually come out slightly wider. The calibration object is 100mm on X and Y axis and 50mm on the Z-Axis. You can then calibrate your STEPS using this formula: X,Y-Axis: 100 / [measured length in mm] [current STEPS]
Z-Axis: X,Y-Axis: 50 / [measured height in mm] [current STEPS] For example my X Axis X-STEPS were 78.4 and I measured the side to be 99.27:
100/99.27 * 78.4 = 78.97
I repeated this for all Axis. You then can set these values either in the printer itself, or in my case I compiled my MARLIN firmware myself and configured it right in the source code in "Configuration/h":
#define DEFAULT_AXIS_STEPS_PER_UNIT {78.97,79.26,535.44,760*1.1} // default steps per unit for Ultimaker After a second print with the new settings my object measured a correct 100.07 x 100.05 x 50.02mm. Be aware that PLA and ABS loose volume when cooling at different ratios. So that calibration will only be 100% accurate for the material you have done it for. ABS typically has a shrinkage ratio of 0.5% to 0.9% depending on the raw ABS material used by the manufacturer. PLA typically much less. For ExcelFil ABS Filament that shrinkage factor is a low 0.5%. A good way to account for that would be to calibrate your printer to the material you use most first and then print the other material and measure the deviation. Most slicers allow for scaling the source model. Apply the measured scaling factor before slicing and you are all set.

Print with whatever speed is comfortable for your printer to get accurate measurements. I print this at 120mm/s with my Ultimaker.
Took about 35 minutes to print An infill of 10% is sufficient. Make sure you don't confuse X and Y axis after the print as some printers have them reversed.

A few over extruded lines, or a too 'smushed' first layer can give a ~1% error with the 20mm cube. I also like that you show the simple expected / measured * old_steps_mm = new_steps_per_mm formula. It's amazing how complicated some folks on here make it! haha

comments.text:
be aware that your also including any error cause by filament thickness.
A good way to factor that out is to measure from the same side of the calibration print.
spin it around, use the 'depth stick' on the back of it to measure from the right edge to right edge.
This helps seperate out the 'trace width' from the 'steps per mm' calibrations.
important because the 'trace width' seem to varry depending on temperature and the plastics thermal properties (and tip wear, but I dont think that ever really happens)

comments.text: Although I like the idea, and might use it for SMD parts, for "through-hole" parts I've found that a piece of corrugated cardboard (for instance, the flap from an old box) works well -- and has the advantage that I can write the values on the cardboard.  (Pick a piece of cardboard that has the "corrugation holes" showing along the "long" edge, and slip the parts into these holes.)
comments.author: ArizonaClark

comments.text: Yep, that solution works as well and you can even store the components in the cardboard if the corrugation is tight enough. When I'm mocking up an electronic project on a proto-board I do find it easier to toss the parts into these little bins tho. It's just quicker than picking up the cardboard and aiming the lead into the corrugation. I make lots of mistakes so I end up swapping parts out a lot, plus the trays help me organize bigger and non electronic parts that are in cue.
comments.author: ArizonaClark

comments.text: I can see that.  My eyes are getting old, and I find that sometimes my jotting values onto the cardboard is easier than trying to be constantly trying to re-read the markings on the components themselves.  Unfortunately, the cardboard does NOT work well for SMD parts, which, these days, I often end up using.  (I often pick larger power ratings for chip parts than what I really need, just to make it easier to solder!)

title: MPCNC F Z motor plate with bolts

description.text:
This is a modified version of the MPCNC Z motor plate (model F 25mm).

The reason I modified it was that my original F-Z motor plate even when tightened down, slide off.

So I thought why shouldn't it be secured to the Z pipes like the spindle/etc's are?

so using openscad I imported the original model, sliced it into 3 parts, stretched the middle part, then put them back together (that was my version one, not posted here), but that covered up more of the motor shaft so I couldn't access the screws to the coupler.

So I carved a bit out of the side around the motor back to approx size it was originally, but still leaving a thicker area around the shafts.

I also removed from the thicker design a M4 hole and M4 nut shape for the bolt to go through.

Neesd 2 x M4 x 50mm

I even left the original F marking on the design.

You should be able to use this script to change the object for the C and J versions, but since I don't have anything to test them on, I haven't designed for them.

The original creator is welcome to take this mod and fold it back into the original design.

original F Z motor plate STL included in this so that he scripts works. I know if quick openscad render it looks bad, but redo it full render (for STL export) and it works.

title: Vostok R-7 ICBM Soyuz Model rocket

description.text:
I scaled down the blueprint to approximately 1/44th scale, it stands one meter tall. In the list of files there are a few different options of assembly, so figure out what works best for you and your printer!

I designed it to run four A motors and one C motor. I numerically calculated the center of gravity and found it to be fairly stable. I did fly it once so far, it got approximately four meters off the ground. Quite under powered.. Eventually i will print new conical liquid boosters which will accept larger motors.

Frankly, I enjoy having it safely on my desk rather then attempting flight!

comments.text:

Sincerely,
EdisonOM

Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1250852

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=1250852

Using the following options:

base_thickness = 1
text2 = BOB
text1 = PAM
offset_angle = 90

This is a remix of Plainolddave's ornament. The excessive solidness of the original (IMHO) made them too time consuming to print several. So this a cut up version to greatly reduce print times. (Version 2.3 saves a couple hours for me.)

The poles are brought inside the upper and lower hemispheres for printing, eliminating all that fill and support material. Use Thingview to look inside. The upper pole is offset for support material at the bottom if the dish if your slicer needs it.

Also redesigned the trench to self center and integrate an LED holder. The trench is intended to be printed in transparent plastic.

This is created to minimize print time, so in exchange for that, it is intended to super glue together. I may re-roll it for pins though depending on how test print does and fits.

There are also some tiny bits of weirdness from the original model solids I did not change (internal surfaces that shouldn't be there.) but I'm in a bit of a rush so did not try to fix those at all at this time.

12/12 Update: V2.3 fixes DISH problems when slicing, drops poly count quite a bit. Solid is much better than when I first started. test print of trench might get redone as it was hard to clean up (1mm detail with supports). Not fully test printed yet, at your own risk. :)

title: Mild Taser (shock toy)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a voltage converter taken out of an alarm clock that has been used to increase the voltage of 2 1.5v AAA batteries to the point it can be felt. The voltage converter normally decreases 120V to 9v. So for any electrical engineers out there who can figure out what 3v would be converted to if you ran the current though it backwards, knock yourself out, becaue I have no clue what the output is on this thing. Can also connect a 9 volt battery, but the shock is a bit painful.

This is a work in progress and I have not designed the holes for the switch or the nails in the box itself. I just drilled them out post printing. However the switch was purchased from radio shack, and the battery holder was cut out of the alarm clock.

Here's a video of it in action:
https://youtu.be/zbbjyepezFo

You can also shock a circle of people if they all hold hands. Kinda fun, but be careful not to use it on anyone who might be at risk from electrical shock. ie, very young, people with heart conditions, pace makers ect.

description.text:
We didn't like sticking the LED for the DJI A3 flight controller to the bottom of the aircraft because we could not see it from the back of the aircraft while still on the ground so I made this little bracket to mount it under the aircraft.

This allows for access to the USB port and has a bit of cable management built in to hold it firmly and for the connector to fit through the bracket to go to the flight controller.

All that is needed is two pieces of VHB tape to mount the LED to the bracket and the bracket to the aircraft.

description.text:
EDIT 12/12/16: Finished printing out all test pieces. Identified some problem areas and worked to resolve them. Unverified that all new fixes work and print correctly, however I believe they should. Once all the parts are printed out, everything should snap together and have a nice tight friction join!

Let me know how you guys think the scale is. Need to go to the store and pick up some magnets, and then create some holes for them and print with them inside the part. Then when I get around to creating the holsters, they can be held in place via magnet.

EDIT 12/11/16: Latest iteration uploaded. Did some test prints, and found a size that fit comfortably in my hands. Tweaked a few things since my last test print, but overall should still be good size.Keeping the old files in now for posterity.

Things to do:

  • Ensure trigger works with a spring
  • Work on adding slight texture on pistol grips
  • Hollow and Slice parts to fit on a 200mm x 200mm printbed
  • Create working safety switch

Original Post: I loved the concept art for the SCAR Stormtroopers, especially the PIlot. After getting a look at the comics, it appears he uses a pair of SE-14 Blasters. Decided to try to make my own since I'm trying to learn Fusion 360. I know on the actual pistol the two ends have a knurled texture, but I haven't quite been able to figure that out yet.

Have not yet tested for scale; plan on getting on that soon enough. Likely will be a bit on the smaller side.

Currently working on trying to set up the trigger so it'll work in conjunction with a spring, as well as adding detailing on the grips.

This is a simple cap meant to replace broken GameCube joystick tips.

This replaces the rubber section, which often gets worn off after prolonged use. I included multiple styles, my favorite of which is the neg_ridge model (it feels the most similar to the original).

I recommend printing a single cap to test tolerances, then printing the plate and testing out all of the various options. The model is meant to be printed in rigid plastic, and then held on with adhesives (I may work on a ninjaflex or similar version later).

Installation is simple, start by removing all remaining rubber bits from the joystick and then press the cap onto the plastic nub. I used a little bit of blu-tack to keep mine on, but hot glue should work fine.

I really don't recommend doing this to a controller that still has the rubber on, since it almost definitely will result in a worse gaming experience.

title: Rear Case for Programmable Power Supply 50V 5A Model

description.text:
This is a rear case for those cheap variable power supplies. I designed this for the 0-50V 5A model but all the variations appear to look like the same main case/LCD so it will probably work for all of them regardless of the rating so long it looks like the same as one in the picture. For some reason they do not come with a rear case and have the components exposed.

A generous amount of vent holes have been added to the top and rear of the case for cooling. I have never known mine to get hot but I've always ran it at low current and under 24V. It has a heatsink on the unit so I assume it can benefit from cooling at higher loads.

There are clips on the side of the power supply for mounting, but trying to use them would probably mean actually cutting them down since there is not gap between the clip and the face. I opted to just have a void in the case where those clips are and rely on a slip fit instead of modifying the power supply or cutting off the tabs entirely. I assumed most others would probably not want to butcher their unit either for really no gain.

The case has legs that tilt that the LCD to a good position for sitting on a bench making it easier to read and access the controls.

The STL was output in millimeters. Please see the printing notes before printing, as you may want to scale it down slightly. If you are confident in your printer accuracy I would measure your power supply and compare the dimensions in the model and scale in the X and Y accordingly to your desired specs. Mine is scaled about 1.5% larger than measured dimensions to account for shrinkage and because I made the walls 0.06in and when printing with 2 shells they would actually be about 0.075in. In the future I'll be sure to use metric units and make the walls multiples of .4mm or .5mm to so it can shell more accurately.

If you print it as is there is probably no chance it will be undersized though, but if your printer prints very accurate shell models it may need to be shimmed (paper, tape, whatever) to give it a really snug fit since this STL is slighly oversized.

FYI: I highly recommend this power supply for the money, especially if you already have a DC power supply to power it. You have to provide it a power source and it can down convert to any voltage/current from 0V to the max of the input power supply voltage/current. In my case I happened to have a 48V 10A power supply, so I can program it anywhere from 0-48V up to its max rating of 5 amps. I've heard that it is possible to find cheap laptop AC to DC 48V power supplies also. If you only have say a 24V or 12V power supply and don't expect a need for more than that they have even cheaper versions (36V max I think) that might be a better buy. If you don't have a cheap/free source for the supply power for it you would probably be better off buying one of the more traditional bench units. I've seen a good but cheap units with their own built-in power source for under $100 new.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I originally printed this out at dimensions measured from the case but it didn't fit - my walls came out thicker than designed because I used inch units and so when using 2 shells the walls came out thicker, plus I didn't account for shrinkage either. I really thought it could get it to fit really tight regardless with some effort but no such luck. So I increased the dimensions by the amount my print was off by plus a small fudge factor just because I didn't want to have to print it a third time and that's what I've posted here. Even mine was ever so slightly loose so I put a little tape on the inside to snug it up. If you are not concerned about shrinkage or will be using a single shell you could probably reduce it up to 1.5%, but I would probably not reduce it by more than 1%, with 0.5 to 0.75% possibly being a range to get a good tight fit without risking it being undersized.

You do not need to use supports if you orient it correctly with the back of the case (the side that is most covered in holes and the notch in it) facing down. That way the start of the legs are touching the bed and it can easily build out that profile without supports. I printed mine in PLA using a cooling fan.

description.text: This project was created by Scott McCullough and Emily Goroza for the class 391AH, which was a seminar based around Commons Based Peer Production lead by Charles Schweik. The class was structured around Outernet, which is a non-profit that distributes files globally using L-band technology. In this class specifically, we were in contact with schools in Malawi that didn't have Internet because of how rural the schools are and the cost of having Internet in that area. Through Outernet, we transmitted one of the schools information on Computer Science topics. The only thing that is required to receive data from Outernet is and L-Band receiver. The design we created is a housing for the DIY Receiver lantern, which protects the electoral components and provides an easier solution for storing the electronics associated with the lantern. It features a housing for both the electronics and the battery, with cut outs for the required cables. It also has an adjustable mount for the antenna to better position it for maximum bandwidth from the satellite.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

No

Yes

100%

Because of the nature of the PLA filament we used, there were slight errors in the accuracy of our prototype. Some of the parts are small, and the supports required for the print make it a bit time consuming to perfect. We took some time to sand down most of the parts to allow the electrical components to fit better. Also the battery case and electronics case were glued together using Gorilla Glue to keep them together.
Outernet DIY Receiver Kit http://store.outernet.is/products/deluxe-outernet-diy-receiver-kit

This is the second version of our prototype. Differences between 1.0 and this version are slight changes to the sizing of some of the parts to account for tolerances of the PLA filament used. We also separated the antenna holder from the rest of the design to allow for finer adjustments to be made.

title: Igus RJM-01-12 to SC12UU and to SC12LUU blocks

description.text: The printer design that I am working on now, is based on SC12LUUs. As I try to remove weight to get my carriage to move faster, and also to remove noise from the LM12UUs, I have designed this. LM12UU are ID:12mm, OD:21mm, L:30mm I got my hands on DryLin R - Solid polymer bearing model RJM-01-12 But, those are ID:12mm, OD:22mm, L:32mm So, they could not fit in my SC12LUU blocks. And at any rate, since I wanted to shed some weight, but keep my design intact, I retrofited thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:18993 to fit the IGUS bearing, and to fit the size of SC12LUU blocks. While I was at it, I also designed regular size SC12UU blocks. Print without support, but, when you print it, print 2 at a time, and mark them as twin brother, and use only twin brothers on parallel applications. Using twin brother parts will ensure no height or size difference, which is quite important if you do not wish to have binding effects while moving your carriage. (don't ask how I know) Enjoy.

Uses M5 screws at the bottom, like any SC12xUU block would.  
Uses M4 screws 25mm long to screw the top, to squeeze the bearing in place.

description.text: This battery holder sits inside the circular hatch on my Hobie kayak. It holds a 12V battery for powering a fishfinder and night light.

Printer:

FlashForge Dreamer

Doesn't Matter

Yes

Doesn't matter

Notes:

This battery holder sits neatly inside the kayak's circular hatch, and is held securely when the hatch lid is closed.

The 12V battery is quite heavy and so the top lip of the battery holder will be under some tension during normal use. To make it as strong as possible I printed this model on its side. Prints are typically stronger in the X-Y plane than in the Z direction. Printing on its side means a lot of support material is required.

The print took around 30 hours on my printer, but the end result is strong, light and great!

print_settings.Notes:: I was being kind of lazy, and didn't want to change my spool so I used PLA. Due to the weight of the box, and that I was using PLA, I built it with 100%, and .1 resolution. It's on the bottom of a 60lb (4) 10s speaker cabinet and it's holding up pretty good.

description.text:
I moved one of my speaker cabinets and found that I lost one of the feet, this is a plastic version of the rubber foot I lost. It's an exact match, so I'd only have to make one of them. I decided to post this here because I'm building some speaker stands for my living room, this came out very nicely so I'm going to make 8 of these, figured someone else might wanna try them out.

UPDATE
I built my set of 8 for my home speaker stands I built I posted a picture. I've spent a LOT of time and effort to make sure I'm getting the cleanest prints possible, but these turned out kind of ugly when compared to my other builds. In the picture you can see the print didn't come out smooth like a .1 resolution should, moisture is the blame. Here's how much humidity has on your prints; I'm currently doing some home remodeling, and it's time to work on my office. Because of this, I've moved most of my stuff to the garage while I'm building the office. I've been printing with no issues until this week. What's the change? It started raining nearly every day. I figured it couldn't have absorbed moisture that quickly, but I was wrong. Luckily the only filament that was in the garage was my Natural PLA. I'll post a pic of my new print once I get my printer back indoors, and print it with non-water soaked ABS. :'(

description.text: Golf tee that may or may not work for all practical purposes. It will hold a ball and stick into the ground. My suggestion is to print horizontally if you'd like it to survive a few (or more?) swings. I don't play golf as you can tell, but this was an off-shoot design from another one I was making for a friend. Hope you find it practical.

Mini Kossel

Yes

.2

High, at least 80%

Boeing 737 Wet Compass e.g. for use with FSX and Mobiflight for homecockpit. The Compass is driven by a stepper motor 28BYJ-48. If the compass rose is printed in white, it can be backlit with a white LED mounted in the motorplate.

CTC Replicator Dual

No

No

0.2 mm

80%

print_settings.Notes:: Print solid, or a high % infill, no support required - no overhangs and CA glue the two parts together. The pointy end has a 2mm wide/deep hole to force fit inside a small steel ball bearing. A ball point pen tip may work too.

description.text:
Inspired by those insanely rare and expensive metal spinning tops, I tried to make one for 3d printing. It would be a cool experiment to try that bronze/metal filled material.

Print solid, or a high % infill, no support required - no overhangs and CA glue the two parts together. The pointy end has a 2mm wide/deep hole to force fit inside a small steel ball bearing. A ball point pen tip may work too.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker Original

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

100

Notes:

Print solid, or a high % infill, no support required - no overhangs and CA glue the two parts together. The pointy end has a 2mm wide/deep hole to force fit inside a small steel ball bearing. A ball point pen tip may work too.

title: Drone It Yourself Printable Parts V1.0

description.text: This is a open project called "Drone it yourself". It allows you to 3d print parts to make a drone, then use everyday objects as the frame.

First, Print these parts 4 x motor_mount – the part that holds the motor
4 x clamp.stl – the main body of the clamp
4 x clamp_bar.stl – the small block that forms the other end of the clamp
4 x bolt_handle.stl – a
1 x box_top.stl
1 x box_bottom.stl Next, get these parts
16 x Plain washer, M3 (4 for each motor) – 189-620
16 x Hex socket cap screw, M3x20mm (4 for each motor) – 293-325
4 or 8 x Wing nut, M4 (1 for each clamp, or 2 if you use the extenders) – 521-850
8 / 16 x Plain washer, M4 (2 for each clamp, or 4 if you use the extenders) – 189-636
4 / 8 x Hex socket cap screw, M4x30mm (1 for each clamp, or 2 if you use the extenders) – 290-118
4 x Hex bolt, M4x60mm (1 for each clamp) – 279-571
4 x Mex nut, M6 (1 for each clamp) – 189-591 Now, Assemble the Clamps That will hold your Propellors, Motors and Electronics (Refere to the Last picture in the slideshow for the assembly) Now, get your electronics 4 x Motor
1 x Propeller kit (2 times left and 2 times right rotating)
1 x Propeller accessory pack
4 x ESC (electronic speed controller)
1 x Radio receiver (with a minimum of four channels)
1 x Flight Controller More coming soon

These things are not for a look

The three holes are for hooking or bolting things on the shelf, I've got a basket that has posts that align with them

title: Christmas Stocking Container
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The Christmas Stocking Container is a screw cap container that looks like a Christmas Stocking. At standard scale the internal storage area is 35mm in diameter and 80mm tall... so plenty of space for small treats!

This is an easy print but does require good build plate adhesion to ensure the stocking prints well. Print the cap in white and the stocking in red...

This design can be scaled up but scaling down will result in insufficient thread clearance so the cap and stocking won't screw together correctly. Printed at standard scale on a well set up PLA machine with a filament fan, the parts should screw together easily straight off the build plate.

Please refer to the instruction, print settings and images for additional information.

Note: if you like this check out the rest of my fun and practical designs!

title: Douilles Guidage Axe Y / LM8UU Téflon

description.text:
Ma Dagoma Discovery 200 a totalement détruit ses 'roulements' linéaires (made in china / 2€ pièce) de qualité 'douteuse', et en même temps totalement 'usiné' les tiges de guidage avec de belles rainures axiales !
Plutôt que les remplacer par la même 'Mer_e', et rendre en même temps ce guidage isostatique, j'ai réalisé deux douilles élastiques (sans jeu) pour y glisser des tubes téflon. Il faut une douille de chaque, vu que l'une assure une fonction 'guidage long', et donc l'autre ne doit être qu'un appui ponctuel sur 'plan'.

Il faut donc glisser dans chaque douille imprimée un bout de tube téflon de diamètre intérieur 8mm, coupé à peu près à la bonne longueur. Attention, à bien orienter la douille 'plan' ! Sinon, ça sert à rien que Ducros se décarcasse ...

Just try to put it in english, just in case my french is not so clear !
My beautiful Dagoma printer destroyed by inadvertance his linear bearings for Y axis (LM8UU made in china).
So, I designed 2 new parts, which are in fact olders for pieces of PTFE cutted pipes. You need one of each, as their function is complementary to obtain a isostatic guidance.

In fact, just add 2 pieces of 8mm PTFE pipe through those bushings. Be carefull at the angular orientation for the 'plan' bushing when inserting inside your machine !

author: lgarciausb

title: Aluminum Heated Build Plate for 3D Printer

description.text:
Aluminum Heated Build Plate It was designed to be used as heated build surface of typical 3d printer with 200 x 200 mm XY build area. Plate is compatible with MK2, MK2A and MK2B heat bed PCBs. Material is 4mm thick T6061-T6 aluminum alloy. Plate has sufficient thickness to prevent twists and to maintain high flatness across whole building area.
Thing uses countersunk mounting screws to eliminate possibility of hot end to run into a screw and damage itself. Another convenient feature is the milled channel for thermistor installation on the bottom of the plate. This feature makes assembly easy and clean, thermistor wiring is hidden in between plate and heated bed PCB. Anodized aluminum plate kits for purchase:
http://reprapchampion.com/build-plate-short-kit
http://reprapchampion.com/build-plate-full-kit
http://www.ebay.com/itm/321336349749 Plate design features:
  • Thick 4mm plate maintains flatness across whole area.
  • Scratch resistant anodized surface.
  • Hidden countersunk mounting screws.
  • Kit uses high temperature resistant silicone rubber spacers instead of typical springs.
  • Thermistor is hidden in the milled channel on the bottom of the plate.

If you wish to build this plate yourself:
  • Consult with drawings and supplied BOM.
  • Great source of raw materials is onlinemetals.com go there and buy 12" x 12" x 1/8" 6061-T6 aluminum alloy sheet. 1/8" material is thinner than 4mm, but still can be used with success.
  • Cutting thick aluminum without CNC mill or router could be hard. Assuming builder has an access to CNC router and CAM software - supplied STL or STEP file can be used to generate G-code. 1/8" 2-flute endmill at high rpm could do cutting job on aluminum plate.
  • Source for all hardware is mcmaster.com. See BOM for part numbers.
  • Connecting bridge for MK2B is not really necessary, if you build plate yourself. M2 mounting hardware for connecting power cable can be omitted too - soldering the wires directly to PCB connecting pads would work.
  • High temperature thick wall silicone rubber tubing is great to make spacers and replace old fashion springs. See BOM for mcmaster part number.

comments.text:
Hello RP One Labs,
Please confirm the thickness in the Thingiverse details of 4mm, the links provided in the details show plates thickness of 3mm.
comments.author: philippe07024

comments.text:
Hi Friend,
We started with 4mm thickness, but later decided to go down to 3mm or 1/8" to lower the weight of moving mass on Y axis. 3mm still can give enough flatness. If you make it yourself you can make your own decision about tickness - both 4mm and 3mm are good, just mass is different.
comments.author: philippe07024

comments.text: The 4 points attachment with screws and springs of my current plate leads to warping. It must be a cheap alloy. I understand the weight concern. Would the 6061-T6 alloy improve my warping issues?
comments.author: rp_one_labs

comments.text: We manufacture our plates on factory from 6061-T6 aluminum, they are cut and lightly brushed on CNC machines, results are satisfactory. I never tried to cut it from soft aluminum because it is not machinable. It must be soft aluminum, yes, but it does not necessarily mean that you need to cut it from stronger aluminum. Use granite countertop as a flatness measure and try to de-bend it little by little, checking against countertop. You should get it perfectly flat in 2-3 minutes. It is not difficult with 6061-T6 and should be even easier with soft alloy.

description.text:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PApb6oIx2Ew&feature=youtu.be
Kit Business Cards seem pretty cool...
Fidget toys seem pretty cool...
Gears are love Gears are life.

And then this Frankenstein's Monster happened.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

100%

Notes:

1 hour print on my end.

Removing from the print plate

Slow and steady wins the race

General notes.

You could go ahead and give a little trip to the gears where they were connected to the Edge for a finer result.

Putting it together

I used a vice and it basically solved all of my problems here,
Although I am sure a hammer or a strong friend would do just fine.

Violence is permitted.

Inventor by Autodesk

2016 Student edition, highly recommended. I have included the Inventor file if you want to change or check anything, a good opportunity to learn as any!

Adding your own text

I have included 2 ZIP files, one with a name, extract the contents to a normal folder.
If you have Inventor 2016 or newer on your computer just open the Assembly file, where is says "Text" you double click a few times until you go into edit mode, Change what you like.

Use the arrow on the top right to go back to the part and click extrude, you go extrude the text outward or inward (removing matter).

Use the arrow again to go to the assembly and click on the little "I" on the top left, go to "Export" and "CAD FORMAT". Change file type to "STL" if it isn't already set to it and enjoy you personal fidget card!

(Spur Gears are found under the "Card" folder)

description.text: Remix of a 8mm-5mm coupler with a flat surface added to the 5mm hole so that it fits weel on the motor shaft.

comments.text:
How to introduce "wobble" :)
Now, let's see the magic solution to tame it !
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
Actually it suppresses wobble coming from coupler's misalignement. Then to reduce wobble coming from the screwed rod you can use this : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1622887
That's what I do and results are pretty nice.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
Not true, these couplers are as bad as the cheap chinese ones. BUT the chinese couplers CAN be made better !
As for your anti wobble solution it is a JOKE ! You MAY reduce it ! People have posted here at least THREE so called solutions, NONE good, just from not bad to totally WRONG !
comments.author: RugbyGoth

comments.text: Perhaps your experience is not the same as mine. The wobble on my Geeetech Prusa i3 ProB was very noticeable before this and now it's bearly noticeable even at the touch.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
My experience is that I know about mechanic and can see design errors. Here they are obvious ! As I said, all these "solutions" may work or may make things worse because they don't eliminate the source of the problem !
Here, most hobbyist have absolutely no clue, no knowledge or minimal in mechanic, let even say basic physic and math and therefore rely more on guess, trial and errors, luck !
comments.author: RugbyGoth

comments.text:
Ok. You seem to assume that I know nothing, but I'm not John Snow, like you I'm an engineer and I can understand things if you will to explain them. Your comments are, from the beginning, at the edge of hatefullness when all I try to do is to share my experience and try to help others.
"Designs errors are obvious" : please explain
"They don't eliminate the source of the problem" : Please explain what the source of the problem is!
So, I saw your solution for this wobble problem. 1 motor for both threaded rods, you've got a point, no more coupler needed and no problem with motor differences, but if your threaded rods are not perfect, you'll still have wobble and you know they will never be perfect!
So, what do we do?
My experience with that printer and those "fix" is that the results are much better and I'm happy with that. If you have something better to propose... Then you can propose it!
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
I stated that I replaced the M8 and why. When I assembled the machine, I saw what was wrong from the start. The way I modified my Prusa was not just to get rid of the wobble. In fact I had almost none as I ensured the M8 was straight and the coupling aligned. Just played a bit with the as is Geetech to be able to get familiar with 3D printing. Then I looked at ways to make it better.
Just for the fun.
In fact, currently just the frame although reinforced is still "original". I used this machine to test my own hot end, extruder etc... I don't publish.People prefer spool holders, proximity sensors, guides ....
I don't make "cool" and "nice" looking stuff, just functional :)
The Prusa is a dead end anyway and now I am looking for a new approach.
I propose you modify the machine as I did and you will see.
comments.author: RugbyGoth

comments.text: Ok I'll give it a try in a few time. I'm happy with what I have now and have plenty of things to print for other projects. Next time I'll give a go to improvment on my printer I'll try your solution. Thanks!
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: Ok I'll give it a try in a few time. I'm happy with what I have now and have plenty of things to print for other projects. Next time I'll give a go to improvment on my printer I'll try your solution. Thanks!

J'ai créé cette chose pour pomper la perchlorure de fer, sans pompe ou autre pièces de métal. L'effet venturi est la meilleur solution pour ça. Il fonctionne avec un pression de 35/40 Psi (2.4 bar environ). La hauteur d'aspiration est d'environ 30 cm. Si vous voulez le fichier SOLIDWORKS est disponible.

I based my design off of Johann's standard effector to fit the E3D hotend.  I wanted to recess it as far as I could while keeping the autolevel probe.  This uses the standard autolevel probe mount but with a added hole to use teflon tube to support the probe from wobbling.  I use the standard teflon tube for 1.75mm filament and ream it out to accomidate a 2mm allen key as the probe.  This gives you about 3mm of travel from the hotend tip to the deployed probe tip.  The config.h settings are 20mm offset and the z probe is 21.5 offset in the y direction if mounted the standard way.
print the effector and the clamp.  The clamp will fit in the groove of the E3D heatsink to hold it in.

comments.text: The large hole for the NEMA and the rings are the reasons why I add the support. My experience is, that there is no problem to print round holes. But it is a lot of trouble to remove accurately support material out the holes. I had no problems with printing the holes without any support material.

Anyone familiar with the great Belgian beer Duvel will know the iconic shape of it's glass. The glasses vary in size from 16cl to 3l, but very tiny ones are not sold.

This shotglass has the original shape of a real Duvel glass, but tiny. Just enough for a shot of your favorite drink.

Clean printed things thoroughly or trow them away after a few uses. Small indents between layers can keep drink remnants and grow some nasty bacteria.

Printer:

Homemade, own design

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.4mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Print with some support around the base of the glass.
Make sure your printer can print water tight.
Print in any color or go with transparent filament.
The base is very brittle if not filled up 100%. You won't save much filament anyway.
The glass weighs around 20g.

Remove the support and clean the base.
Go with a scraper on the inside to remove any tiny particles before you drink them.
Clean the glass
Put some water in it and leave it for a few hours to check if it can hold water
Clean the glass after usage or trow it out!

The model is based on an image of a real Duvel glass that was loaded into a sketch. The glass was scaled down but thickness of the walls was not. A shotglass of any iconic glass of a ( Belgian ) beer can be created this way.

remixed_from.author: aspesilorenzo
remixed_from.title: Parametric Z-axis coupler (stepper and threaded rod coupling)

description.text:
this is a coupler with M8 thread, and acts as a spacer to prevent from pulling on the motor.
this is for the old z-tower of mpcnc. dont forget the bearing in the tower. on my motor there is enough space to attach to the internal bearing. if there is not enough space you have to add an additional bearing on the motor side/ and to change the coupler..

thanks to aspesilorenzo for his design

this is not designed to reduce the wobble of your m8 rod / it could be worse depending of the 3d print and the alignment. it solves only the problem if you need to push against the table with force (drag knife / drag roller)

comments.text:
If you want to be more constructive your welcome...
but for this the answer is
comments.author: chriswal

comments.text: That reminds me of a jerk who used that motto and failed !
comments.author: chriswal

comments.text: not constructive at all :-)
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: If people reading this can avoid wasting their time with this "thing" that is likely to worsen the wobble, it is worthwhile, YES ! Spreading bad designs should not be allowed !
comments.author: chriswal

comments.text:
yes you are right ..it "could" worsen the wobble.but it solves a specific problem for me when you have to push against the table with force. you will never do this with a 3d printer.(if you align it, its not worse than the original one sided clamp from the MPCNC Design.) at least it works for me.
yes you are right .. the solution with M8 rods are not perfect (you probably wont get a perfect straight rod) but its the cheapest way for motion where you need force. Also there is the problem with 3d printed parts.they are never that perfect at machined one.
So for the perfect path we would need:
a self aligning motor mount
a self aligning coupler
self aligning bearings
a self aligning nut
and a perfect straight m8 rod
all that designed to handle force and without mechanical play
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: See in my "things" how I solve this in my Geetech Prusa. Principle applicable to other Prusa.
comments.author: chriswal

comments.text: Why do people keep publishing bad designs that will introduce problems.
comments.author: MKSA

print_settings.Notes:: SUPPORTS ARE ONLY NEEDED FOR BLADES

description.text:
This is a remix! Credit to Skimbal

Remixed:
I have made the bottom inlet port bigger with a adapter that will adapt to a 12mm dia pipe, the blades have been remade to have less of a curve (as seen in photos) as well as the casing wall has been thickened to let the water to be held for a little bit longer before being thrown out of the outlet pipe. (also seen in picture) The outlet pipe has been extended to produce a better grip as well as transferring from a larger hole to a smaller in the process.

The reason for the design change is so it is used as a RC boat Ballast pump.

Motor mount is in the design process!

Any questions leave in the comments and ill get back to them ASAP!

Printer:

Da Vinici Jr.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Med-High

Infill:

15-20%

Notes:

SUPPORTS ARE ONLY NEEDED FOR BLADES

comments.author: WaveSkyLord

comments.text: No, the blade has to face the inlet port inorder to suck in the water. Both pumps I have printed are the same way and both work perfectly
